items.author: Rick Groen
items.content: It's intriguing, appalling, savvy, nasty, grossly unsettling -- you may not like what you see, but you'll definitely be affected by the sight.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: A dark, grisly, horrifying and intelligent thriller.

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: This homicide thriller has a tantalizingly morbid atmosphere of unease.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: While Seven lacks the cleverness of the superior "Usual Suspects," it's strong enough to hold its own against most other thrillers.

items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: It's not the identity of the killer that gives Seven its kick -- it's the way Fincher raises mystery to the level of moral provocation.

items.author: Mike Clark
items.content: Director David Fincher shovels on more gloom than even the serial killer genre can sustain in the murkily moody, but self-defeating, Seven.

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: It is very tiresome peering through the gloom trying to catch a glimpse of something interesting, then having to avert one's eyes when it turns out to be just another brutally tormented body.

items.author: Sean Means
items.content: Watching Seven is like cracking open a safe, only to find it crawling with eels

items.author: David Ansen
items.content: A style so chic, studied and murky it resembles a cross between a Nike commercial and a bad Polish art film.

items.author: Elvis Mitchell
items.content: Not even bags of body parts, a bitten-off tongue or a man forced to cut off a pound of his own flesh keep it from being dull. [22 September 1995, p. C18]
